awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Rapid computational modeling of wildfires and management with emphasis on human activity
awd_abstract_narration:
Accurate short-term predictions of wildfire spread are essential to inform people, minimize the loss of lives and mitigate damage and cost of wildfire through effective suppression activities. It is critical to improve on these processes in the aftermath of the devastation of the Lahaina Fires. Before details are forgotten, it is critical to identify all the factors influencing wildfire spreads and to determine how to incorporate them into the rapid prediction process. This project will train Ph.D. students in computational science and modeling. This project will involve high school and community college students from the `Aina Data Stewards program on Maui.
 
This project will develop wildfire models that have the potential to save human lives and infrastructure in future wildfires using level-set methods and Hamilton-Jacobi equations to model wildfire spread coupled to human activity during and after wildfire activity in residential zones. While level-set methods are relatively well known for wildfire modeling with coupling to data assimilation methods for real-time analysis, there is need to understand their interaction with human activity especially as it relates to evacuation and protection of property immediately after a wildfire event. A product of this research will be a new model to provide an understanding of the complex algorithmic and mathematical basis for wildfire response that can aid in resource allocation in a virtually real-time disaster situation such as the Lahaina firestorm. This project will show how to immediately deploy this model to avert the bottlenecks leading to tragedy and the required technological advances necessary to implement paradigm-shifting solutions in fire management techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary

This NSF-funded project sought to enhance our understanding and modeling of wildfire spread in residential zones, focusing on the interaction between wildfire behavior and human activity. The work combined mathematical modeling, remote sensing, and geospatial data analysis to address a pressing need for more accurate fire prediction tools, particularly in Maui County, Hawaii. The project outcomes significantly contribute to intellectual merit by advancing mathematical and computational techniques, and to broader impacts by providing actionable data and insights to stakeholders.

Intellectual Merit

The project aimed to develop innovative methods for modeling wildfire spread by coupling level set methods and Hamilton-Jacobi equations with fine-scale geospatial and remote sensing data. PI Kerner’s team created geospatial datasets that will serve as inputs for these models, including vegetation cover, land use/land cover, digital elevation models, and vegetation dryness, derived from the Global Vegetation Moisture Index (GVMI). This integration will allow models to more accurately reflect the complex topography and microclimates of Maui County, which standard or coarse-grained models fail to capture.

A significant achievement was the creation of detailed remote sensing datasets relevant to wildfire dynamics. These datasets were curated to provide precise observations of environmental variables such as vegetation dryness and fuel loads. Such high-resolution inputs are critical for developing reliable models of wildfire behavior, especially in regions with diverse landscapes like Maui County.

The research also extended its intellectual contributions through education and dissemination. PI Kerner taught a guest lecture on using and interpreting remote sensing datasets for modeling wildfire spread, as part of a course led by PI Andrea Bertozzi at UCLA. This lecture equipped students with practical knowledge of integrating geospatial data into mathematical modeling, fostering interdisciplinary learning and research.

Broader Impacts

Dr. Kerner presented maps of GVMI and other geospatial datasets to the Maui County Department of Agriculture and County Council, equipping them with data to better assess fire conditions and manage resources.

The data products created for this project extend beyond fire applications. These geospatial datasets hold value for other environmental studies, such as species distribution modeling and biodiversity impact assessments. 

Furthermore, the project addressed a critical gap in wildfire modeling for Maui County. Currently, there are no reliable models for estimating wildfire spread or fuel loads in the region. By incorporating fine-scale observations from remote sensing into mathematical models, this research will lay the groundwork for predictive tools that can help communities prepare for and respond to wildfire events more effectively.
